Coffee is believed to have originated in Ethiopia, where legend suggests that a goat herder named Kaldi noticed his goats becoming more energetic after eating the berries of a certain plant. He tried the berries himself and discovered their energizing effects, leading to the cultivation and spread of coffee plants throughout the Arabian Peninsula.

Coffee became an important crop in the Arab world, where it was roasted and brewed into a drink. The first coffeehouses opened in Egypt in the 16th century and were initially places for socializing, discussing politics, and listening to music. Coffeehouses soon spread throughout the Arab world and into Europe, becoming popular among intellectuals and eventually the general public.

The popularity of coffee continued to grow, especially with advancements in technology that made it easier to transport and prepare. Coffee became a major commodity trade, with countries like Brazil and Colombia becoming major producers. Today, coffee is enjoyed by people all over the world and has become an important part of many cultures, from Italian espresso to Turkish coffee to American drip coffee.
